content: With the reduction in #91449 , I think I can say fairly confidently that this is an issue in LLVM. I've filed a bug report there, although I'm not sure if it can be fixed - is it worth keeping the rust issue open to track that, or should I close it with "whatever ends up happening in LLVM, there's nothing we can do here"?

Personally, I think that for something as micro as that I'd say it might as well just be closed on the rust side. (Since you did such a good job of reducing!) We'll pick it up once it's fixed and released, and I don't see anyone getting blocked my the lack of it.

I think it's only worth tracking it on the rust side if it's a bigger thing, like it's important to the alloc removal optimizations or important for getting autovectorization to work reliably with Rust's less-UB semantics or important for stabilizing std::simd or something.
That sounds good, I've closed it for now. If there's more developments in the future, its always possible to reopen then in any case.
Right. Especially now that it's easy to follow the LLVM issue and thus for someone to re-open it on the rust side once the fix lands in LLVM.
